Alas, the Lack
This campus is without co-eds, athletic interest,
school spirit, adequate parking space, and physical
beauty. There is, however, another lack which should
have priority for correction.
To turn a phrase, "a lot of learning is a dangerous
thing." Too easily the undergraduate, whether intense
for knowledge or enrolled by chance and the new convention of taking a degree, adapts to the rarified air of
academia by hermetically sealing himself off from the
less pure airs of our larger society. Social concern is not
a luxury that we can do without, but a necessity for the
human vitality of any community; it is a commodity that
we possess only in the accidental minimum of inevitability.
It is inevitable that a few of the thousands of men
who inhabit or frequent this island, Hopkins, must be
aware of problems outside these confines and willing to
act toward their solution. So CONCERN has come and
gone, to he fortunately superseded by the Students for a
Democratic Society. After these very active agents of
liberal thought come the Young Democrats and Young
Republicans, which groups deserve the name of organized awareness, if not the name of action. These groups
comprise a minority upon which most of us look with
disdain, if at all. Perhaps we are peculiar in our attitude
and ignorance, for on the campuses of other "best"
colleges and universities, political thought and social
action are an accepted part of life, if not the ruling
passion.
We really have no right to feel that the demands of
individuality prevent our involvement with the faceless
mass of society. The beat generation has grown up, and
seems to have been replaced here by a generation of
lazy self-interest. We need not ask ourselves to jump in
and conform, as that is not the issue. The issues are
unemployment and poverty, prejudice and injustice, war
and peace. We need to think and act, after deciding to
care, rather than ignore in a comfortable apathy.
No doubt we all agree that the university life should
be a human experience as well as an educational one;
that an educated individual and a mature social being
should he one and the same product here. Maturity as
perceived in the serious undergraduate-in-a-fog is but an
illusion if maturity means to be fully grown. To be a
grown and functional human being involves a great deal
of distinctively human responsibility that most of us will
not be able to ignore forever. Though each man's first
responsibility is to himself, if not to God, the rest of
Jinen cannot be ignored.
Upon graduation, most of us will have social involvement thrust upon us by the exigencies of occupation and housekeeping in some community. Why wait?
'Why separate ourselves from the world as long as passible? Far from deserving this little vacation on the
green and in the stacks, as future leaders in the world we
need some education in its ways. A man not involved
with the rest of the world is an island, and a handful
of dust is the lowest state of man.

Coming Exam
The next few weeks will test the fortitude, patience,
and understanding of many Hopkins undergraduates.
As reported in today's paper, the Student Council will
begin discussing religious and racial discrimination in
fraternities Monday night.
Student leaders have been quietly discussing the
problem for several months. They know that the issue
of discrimination is charged with the emotion that usually leads to the formation of two adamant and opposing
groups. Students recognize the problem, but they know
that it cannot be solved unless an outburst of that emotion is prevented.
No solution will he found unless fortitude and

academia by hermetically sealing himself off from the
less pure airs of our larger society. Social concern is not
a luxury that we can do without, but a necessity for the
human vitality of any community; it is a commodity that
we possess only in the accidental minimum of inevitability.

who inhabit or frequent this island, Hopkins, must be
